Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Game-Based Neuro-Cognitive Assessment Tool for School Readiness
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase I project's objective is to promote school readiness for Pre-K and Kindergarten students by providing support for neuro-cognitive skills, such as executive functioning and reasoning, shown to be critical for school success. The first aim is to build a prototype of a game-based assessment tool for these skills that can be implemented in classrooms to measure these skills as a baseline and to track and measure progress over time. If proven feasible, the prototype is expected to assess a child's skills in five neuro-cognitive areas in 10-15 minutes with minimal adult intervention and provide recommendations for further support. Phase I of this project will focus on developing the prototype, testing usability and feasibility with Pre-K students and teachers, and collecting data to calibrate the tool using factor analysis and item-response theory. The broader impact of this research is to gather rich data that will advance the scientific community's understanding of cognitive development in relation to multiple factors and to increase the ability to evaluate the impact of targeted interventions. In addition, commercialization of the proposed tool will help increase teachers' and caregivers' awareness of these skills and shift classroom practices towards fostering the critical underlying skills for school readiness.

This project will build a prototype using constructs that are based on neuropsychological tasks designed to target these skills in lab research. Five skills will be included in the prototype: working memory, inhibitory control, cognitive flexibility, reasoning and spatial skills. First, results from a convergent reliability study fielded in spring 2016 comparing Pre-K students' performance in these constructs vs. normed reference tests will be used to refine and improve the reliability of the constructs. Next, the prototype will undergo usability and feasibility testing with Pre-K students and teachers. The goal is to optimize the experience such that it can be completed in a single 15-minute session with minimal adult intervention. Finally, data will be gathered to calibrate the tool using factor analysis and item-response theory to refine the test branching algorithms. At the end of Phase I, the prototype will be ready for further research to normalize the results nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Executive functioning [EF] skills, along with other neuro-cognitive skills, are critical to children’s abilities to learn and be successful in school. These skills are malleable and children as young as three years old can be supported to make substantial improvements, thereby building a stronger foundation for school success. EF skills vary with children’s socio-economic status, and children with low SES levels are particularly susceptible to having low levels of EF skills. Most schools and early childcare centers today do not have programs to address these skills even though targeted interventions are shown to have impact.

 

The objective of Phase I was to develop a working prototype of a tablet-based digital screener for neuro-cognitive skills for young children. The goal of the screener is to assess and identify children who may be in need of supplemental supports, or further in-depth assessment.  A working prototype was developed that included five test modules and a backend to collect score data. Five assessment modules were developed to assess working memory, inhibitory control, reasoning, spatial ability and flexibility. The tasks were designed from other paper-based or in-person assessments targeting these skills. Each assessment module comprised three distinct sections: a tutorial, a series of practice trials, followed by the assessment. The back-end logic of the assessment was structured as an item bank and scores were tabulated for each session.

 

Usability testing was conducted with 5 Pre-K teachers and 8 students  on the test modules, to collect feedback for product iterations. Finally, feasibility testing including test reliability was conducted in 7 classrooms across 4 preschool centers to determine the functioning of the app and to examine teachers’ and children’s use of and comprehension of the app as well as the individual test items. The one week of app implementation in seven preschool classrooms indicated that while  teachers’ implementation styles varied, teachers were able to implement the app in their classroom’s normal routines. Teachers also expressed that the content in the app was appropriate to measure children’s cognitive skills and they would use the app as an assessment with their students.

 

Our work in Phase I demonstrated the feasibility of a digital screener for neuro-cognitive skills used in preschool settings. Further product refinements and a teacher-facing professional development component are a few necessary additions to complete the offering and prepare it for commercialization.
